conclusion: The problem involves determining the velocity of an object at displacement x1 using the given acceleration-displacement graph.
The graph shows acceleration (a) as a function of displacement (x). Acceleration is constant at a0 for 0 ≤ x ≤ x2, and decreases linearly to 0 for x2 ≤ x ≤ x3.
For 0 ≤ x ≤ x2, the acceleration is constant at a0, and the velocity can be calculated using the kinematic equation v^2 = v0^2 + 2a1(x - x0).
Substituting v0 = 0, a1 = a0, and x0 = 0 into the equation, the velocity at x = x2 is v2 = sqrt(2a0x2).
For x2 ≤ x ≤ x3, the acceleration is given by a = a0 - (a0 / (x3 - x2))(x - x2).
The velocity for x2 ≤ x ≤ x3 can be found by integrating the acceleration: v = ∫a dx = ∫(a0 - (a0 / (x3 - x2))(x - x2)) dx.
The integral of the acceleration yields v = a0x - (a0 / (x3 - x2))((x - x2)^2 / 2) + C.
Using the boundary condition at x = x2, where v = v2 = sqrt(2a0x2), the constant C is determined to be sqrt(2a0x2).
The velocity as a function of x for x2 ≤ x ≤ x3 is v = a0x - (a0 / (x3 - x2))((x - x2)^2 / 2) + sqrt(2a0x2).
At x = x1, the velocity is v = a0x1 - (a0 / (x3 - x2))((x1 - x2)^2 / 2) + sqrt(2a0x2).
Using the work-energy theorem, the work done by the force F is equal to the change in kinetic energy, and the work can be calculated as the area under the acceleration-displacement graph.
The work done for 0 ≤ x ≤ x2 is W1 = ∫0^x2 a0 dx = a0x2.
